instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is a common issue in both new and old buildings?
output: Most of the buildings either new or old have operational faults in the sensors controllers meters equipment and systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: Why is it important to model and simulate faults in buildings?
output: Being able to model and simulate these faults and their impact on energy performance of buildings is crucial to improve accuracy of building simulations and to support the retrofit of buildings.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What has been the main practitioner use of EnergyPlus to date?
output: To date the main practitioner use of EnergyPlus has been for new construction design.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: Why is there a need to extend the capabilities of EnergyPlus?
output: With the new high priority attached by USDOE to retrofit and improved operation of existing buildings there is a need to extend the capabilities of EnergyPlus to model existing buildings including faulty operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is the starting point for retrofit analysis?
output: Retrofit analysis starts with calibrated simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How can commissioning providers use fault models?
output: Commissioning providers can use the fault models to demonstrate the saving to be expected from fixing faults found in retro-commissioning.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How can building operation be supported using the calibrated model?
output: Support for building operation can be achieved by using the calibrated model including unfixed faults as a real-time reference model to detect and verify the diagnosis of newly occurring faults.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: Who are the users of the fault models in the given cases?
output: The users in these cases are practitioners not power users.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: Why is it necessary to implement the fault models using conventional EnergyPlus objects?
output: It is needed to implement the fault models using conventional EnergyPlus objects because the EMS could only be used to model limited types of faults.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does EnergyPlus contain to model operational faults?
output: EnergyPlus contains a number of objects to model operational faults of sensors meters equipment and systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What are the categories of fault types that can be modeled?
output: The current implementation allows the modeling of a number of fault types that are categorized as: (1) sensor faults with air economizers (2) thermostat/humidistat offset faults (3) fouling or scaling at air side or water side components (4) sensor faults with plant components.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Sensor Faults with Air Economizers -> Symptom -> text
input: What causes inappropriate operations of the air economizer?
output: The sensor readings deviate from the actual air conditions due to sensor offset which leads to inappropriate operations of the air economizer.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Sensor Faults with Air Economizers -> Symptom -> text
input: What is the result of inappropriate operations of the air economizer?
output: Inappropriate operations of the air economizer lead to undesired resulting indoor conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Sensor Faults with Air Economizers -> Modeling Approach -> text
input: What supports the air economizer operations?
output: There are a number of sensors installed to support the air economizer operations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Sensor Faults with Air Economizers -> Modeling Approach -> text
input: What types of sensors are used for the air economizer?
output: The sensors may be of different types.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Sensor Faults with Air Economizers -> Modeling Approach -> text
input: What objects are used by EnergyPlus to model sensor faults?
output: The objects used by EnergyPlus to model the sensor faults are: FaultModel:TemperatureSensorOffset:OutdoorAir FaultModel:HumiditySensorOffset:OutdoorAir FaultModel:EnthalpySensorOffset:OutdoorAir FaultModel:TemperatureSensorOffset:ReturnAir FaultModel:EnthalpySensorOffset:ReturnAir.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> Symptom -> text
input: What causes inappropriate operations of the HVAC system?
output: The zone air temperature/relative humidity readings deviate from the actual zone air conditions due to thermostat/humidistat offset leading to inappropriate operations of the HVAC system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> Symptom -> text
input: What is the result of inappropriate operations of the HVAC system?
output: Inappropriate operations of the HVAC system lead to undesired resulting indoor conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> Modeling Approach -> text
input: How is the thermostat offset fault described?
output: The thermostat offset fault is described in the object FaultModel:ThermostatOffset which refers to the object ZoneControl:Thermostat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> Modeling Approach -> text
input: How is the humidistat offset fault described?
output: The humidistat offset fault is described in the object FaultModel:HumidistatOffset which refers to the object ZoneControl:Humidistat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Operational Faults Modeling -> Subsection: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> Modeling Approach -> equation
input: What equation represents the effect of an offset in a thermostat/humidistat?
output: The effect of an offset in a thermostat/humidistat whose sole use is for the calculation of difference between the set-points and the design values can be modeled as an equal and opposite offset in the thermostat/humidistat: \\( T_sf \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What are some examples of sensor faults with plant components?
output: Examples of sensor faults with plant components include chiller supply water temperature sensor offset.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Sensor Faults with Air Economizers -> text
input: What symptom is caused by sensor offset in air economizers?
output: The sensor readings deviate from the actual air conditions due to sensor offset leading to inappropriate operations of the air economizer and undesired resulting indoor conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Sensor Faults with Air Economizers -> text
input: What is the modeling approach for sensor faults with air economizers?
output: There are a number of sensors installed to support the air economizer operations which may be of different types. EnergyPlus models these sensor faults using specific objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Sensor Faults with Air Economizers -> text
input: What objects are used by EnergyPlus to model sensor faults?
output: The objects used by EnergyPlus to model the sensor faults are: FaultModel:TemperatureSensorOffset:OutdoorAir FaultModel:HumiditySensorOffset:OutdoorAir FaultModel:EnthalpySensorOffset:OutdoorAir FaultModel:TemperatureSensorOffset:ReturnAir and FaultModel:EnthalpySensorOffset:ReturnAir.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: What symptom is caused by thermostat/humidistat offset?
output: The zone air temperature/relative humidity readings deviate from the actual zone air conditions due to thermostat/humidistat offset leading to inappropriate operations of the HVAC system and undesired resulting indoor conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: How is the thermostat offset fault described in EnergyPlus?
output: The thermostat offset fault is described in the object FaultModel:ThermostatOffset which refers to the object ZoneControl:Thermostat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: How is the humidistat offset fault described in EnergyPlus?
output: The humidistat offset fault is described in the object FaultModel:HumidistatOffset which refers to the object ZoneControl:Humidistat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> equation
input: What is the equation for the thermostat value in the faulty case?
output: The equation for the thermostat value in the faulty case is \( T_sf = T_sff - \Delta T \).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> equation
input: What is the equation for the humidistat value in the faulty case?
output: The equation for the humidistat value in the faulty case is \( RH_sf = RH_sff - \Delta RH \).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: What do \( T_sf \) and \( T_sff \) represent in the thermostat offset equation?
output: \( T_sf \) is the thermostat value in the faulty case and \( T_sff \) is the thermostat value in the fault-free case (design value).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: What do \( RH_sf \) and \( RH_sff \) represent in the humidistat offset equation?
output: \( RH_sf \) is the humidistat value in the faulty case and \( RH_sff \) is the humidistat value in the fault-free case (design value).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: What does \( \Delta T / \Delta RH \) represent?
output: \( \Delta T / \Delta RH \) represents the difference between the thermostat/humidistat readings and the actual zone air conditions. Positive values mean that the readings are higher than the actual air conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: How is \( \Delta RH \) described for a humidistat independent of the thermostat?
output: For a humidistat that is independent of the thermostat \( \Delta RH \) can be described by a pre-defined schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: How is \( \Delta RH \) calculated when caused by the thermostat offset?
output: For the humidistat offset caused by the thermostat offset \( \Delta RH \) is related to both the thermostat offset level and the dynamic indoor air conditions and is calculated each time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> equation
input: What is the equation for \( \Delta RH \) when caused by the thermostat offset?
output: The equation for \( \Delta RH \) is \( \Delta RH = RH_sff - f(T_real W_sf) \).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: What do \( T_real \) and \( W_sf \) represent in the equation for \( \Delta RH \)?
output: \( T_real \) is the real-time temperature of the indoor air (real value) and \( W_sf \) is the humidistat ratio corresponding to \( T_real - \Delta T \) and \( RH_sff \) measured in kgWater/kgDryAir.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: What are the two major processes related to thermostat/humidistat settings within EnergyPlus?
output: The two major processes are the design load calculations and HVAC system sizing and the HVAC system operations. Only the latter is affected by the thermostat/humidistat offset fault.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Thermostat/Humidistat Offset -> text
input: What happens when EMS is used to overwrite thermostat/humidistat values?
output: When EMS is used to overwrite the ZoneControl:Thermostat/ZoneControl:Humidistat values the offsets are applied to the EMS values rather than the original Thermostat/Humidistat values.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for the thermostat value in the faulty case?
output: T_sf = T_sff - \\Delta T

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for the humidistat value in the faulty case?
output: RH_sf = RH_sff - \\Delta RH

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does T_sf represent?
output: T_sf is the thermostat value in the faulty case °C.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does T_sff represent?
output: T_sff is the thermostat value in the fault-free case (design value) °C.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does RH_sf represent?
output: RH_sf is the humidistat value in the faulty case.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does RH_sff represent?
output: RH_sff is the humidistat value in the fault-free case (design value).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does \\Delta T / \\Delta RH represent?
output: Difference between the thermostat/humidistat readings and the actual zone air conditions. Positive values mean that the readings are higher than the actual air conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How can \\Delta RH be described for a humidistat that is independent of the thermostat?
output: For the humidistat that is independent of the thermostat \\Delta RH can be described by a pre-defined schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How is \\Delta RH related when the humidistat offset is caused by the thermostat offset?
output: \\Delta RH is related to both the thermostat offset level as well as the indoor air conditions which are dynamic and therefore cannot be described with a pre-defined schedule. In this case the humidistat offset level is calculated each time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for \\Delta RH when the humidistat offset is caused by the thermostat offset?
output: \\Delta RH = RH_sff - f(T_real W_sf)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does T_real represent?
output: T_real is the real-time temperature of the indoor air (real value) °C.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does W_sf represent?
output: W_sf is the humidistat ratio corresponding to T_real - \\Delta T and RH_sff kgWater/kgDryAir.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How are thermostat/humidistat settings related to processes within EnergyPlus?
output: The thermostat/humidistat settings are related to two major processes within EnergyPlus: one is the design load calculations and HVAC system sizing and the other is the HVAC system operations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: Which process is affected by the thermostat/humidistat offset fault?
output: Only the HVAC system operations are affected by the thermostat/humidistat offset fault while the design load calculations and HVAC system sizing are not.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: Is the size of HVAC equipment affected by the thermostat/humidistat offset fault?
output: The size of the corresponding HVAC equipment in the faulty cases is the same as that in the fault-free cases.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How are offsets applied when EMS is used to overwrite ZoneControl:Thermostat/ZoneControl:Humidistat values?
output: When EMS is used to overwrite the ZoneControl:Thermostat/ZoneControl:Humidistat values the offsets are applied to the EMS values rather than the original Thermostat/Humidistat values.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Heating and Cooling Coil Fouling -> text
input: What symptom is described for heating and cooling coil fouling?
output: Reduced overall heat transfer coefficient (UA) causes reduced coil capacity resulting in unmet loads and/or increased water flow rate and decreased water side temperature difference (\low delta-T syndrome\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: Which object describes the coil fouling fault?
output: The coil fouling fault is described in the object FaultModel:Fouling:Coil.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: To which type of coils does the fault model currently apply?
output: The fault model currently applies only to the simple water coils: Coil:Heating:Water and Coil:Cooling:Water.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: What methods can be used to describe the fouling information in FaultModel:Fouling:Coil?
output: The FaultModel:Fouling:Coil object allows the user to describe the fouling information in either of the two methods: FouledUARated or FoulingFactor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: How does the FouledUARated method work?
output: Using the FouledUARated method the user specifies the value of UAfouled directly.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: How does the FoulingFactor method work?
output: Using the FoulingFactor method the user specifies air/water side fouling factor and the UAfouled value is further calculated via the equations shown below.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> equation
input: What is the equation for UA_fouled using the FoulingFactor method?
output: UA_fouled = [\\frac1UA_air + R_foul + \\frac1UA_water]^-1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: What does UA_air represent?
output: U_Aair is the heat transfer coefficient of the coil on the air side W/K.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: What does UA_fouled represent?
output: UA_fouled is the overall heat transfer coefficient of the fouled coil W/K.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: What does UA_water represent?
output: UA_water is the heat transfer coefficient of the coil on the water side W/K.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: What does R_foul represent?
output: R_foul is the fouling thermal insulance factor (the reciprocal of a heat transfer coefficient) K/W.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> equation
input: What is the equation for R_foul?
output: R_foul = \\fracr_airA_air + \\fracr_waterA_water

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: What does r_air represent?
output: r_air is the air side fouling factor m^2-K/W.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: What does r_water represent?
output: r_water is the water side fouling factor m^2-K/W.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: What does A_air represent?
output: A_air is the air side coil surface area m^2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> text
input: What does A_water represent?
output: A_water is the water side coil surface area m^2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - General -> equation
input: What is the equation for R_foul given the input of the object based on the outside coil surface area and the inside to outside coil surface area ratio?
output: R_foul = \\fracr_waterA_out*A_ratio + \\fracr_airA_out

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is the impact of reduced overall heat transfer coefficient (UA) on coil capacity?
output: Reduced overall heat transfer coefficient (UA) causes reduced coil capacity resulting in unmet loads and/or increased water flow rate and decreased water side temperature difference (low delta-T syndrome).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What object describes the coil fouling fault?
output: The coil fouling fault is described in the object FaultModel:Fouling:Coil.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: To which coils does the fault model apply?
output: The fault model currently applies only to the simple water coils: Coil:Heating:Water and Coil:Cooling:Water.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What methods does the FaultModel:Fouling:Coil object allow for describing fouling information?
output: The FaultModel:Fouling:Coil object allows the user to describe the fouling information in either of the two methods: FouledUARated or FoulingFactor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How is the UAfouled value specified using the FouledUARated method?
output: Using the FouledUARated method the user specifies the value of UAfouled directly.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How is the UAfouled value calculated using the FoulingFactor method?
output: Using the FoulingFactor method the user specifies air/water side fouling factor and the UAfouled value is further calculated via the equations shown below.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation used to calculate the fouled overall heat transfer coefficient (UAfouled)?
output: UA_fouled = [\\frac1UA_air + R_foul + \\frac1UA_water]^-1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does UA_air represent in the equation for UAfouled?
output: UA_air is the heat transfer coefficient of the coil on the air side W/K.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does UA_fouled represent in the equation?
output: UA_fouled is the overall heat transfer coefficient of the fouled coil W/K.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does UA_water represent in the equation for UAfouled?
output: UA_water is the heat transfer coefficient of the coil on the water side W/K.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does R_foul represent in the equation for UAfouled?
output: R_foul is the fouling thermal insulance factor (the reciprocal of a heat transfer coefficient) K/W.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation used to determine R_foul?
output: R_foul = \\fracr_airA_air + \\fracr_waterA_water

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does r_air represent in the equation for R_foul?
output: r_air is the air side fouling factor m^2-K/W.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does r_water represent in the equation for R_foul?
output: r_water is the water side fouling factor m^2-K/W.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does A_air represent in the equation for R_foul?
output: A_air is the air side coil surface area m^2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does A_water represent in the equation for R_foul?
output: A_water is the water side coil surface area m^2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for R_foul based on the outside coil surface area and the inside to outside coil surface area ratio?
output: R_foul = \\fracr_waterA_out*A_ratio + \\fracr_airA_out

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does A_out represent in the equation for R_foul?
output: A_out is the Outside Coil Surface Area (in contact with the air) m^2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does A_ratio represent in the equation for R_foul?
output: A_ratio is the Inside to Outside Coil Surface Area Ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: Is the pressure drop associated with fouling considered in the current implementation?
output: The pressure drop associated with the fouling is ignored in the current implementation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What schedules are used in the fault modeling approach?
output: An Availability schedule is used to schedule the fault on or off. A Severity Schedule is also used to represent the severity of the fault or Fault Fraction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does a schedule value of 1 indicate in the fault modeling approach?
output: A Schedule value of 1 (default) means that the fault is applied as is.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is determined before applying the fault to a Coil:Heating:Water?
output: Before the fault is applied to a Coil:Heating:Water the current non-fouled UA (WaterCoil(CoilNum).UACoilVariable) is first determined.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How is the new UA set using the FouledUARated method for a heating coil?
output: If method FouledUARated is used we try to set the new UA to the UA_fouled entered in the Fouling Object adjusting for Fault Severity FaultFrac.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for adjusting UA using the FouledUARated method?
output: UA = [\\fracFaultFracUA_fouled+\\frac(1-FaultFrac)UA]^-1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is the equation for R_foul when using the FoulingFactor method for a heating coil?
output: R_foul = FaultFrac \\cdot [ \\fracr_waterA_out*A_ratio + \\fracr_airA_out ]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for adjusting UA using the FoulingFactor method for a heating coil?
output: UA = [\\frac1UA + R_foul]^-1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is the restriction on improving the coil UA in the fault modeling?
output: We do not allow bettering the coil UA so the final result in either case is UA = min(UA UA).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is determined before applying the fault to a Coil:Cooling:Water?
output: Before the fault is applied to a Coil:Cooling:Water the current non-fouled UA_water (WaterCoil(CoilNum).UACoilExternal) and UA_air (WaterCoil(CoilNum).UACoilInternal) are first determined.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How is the FoulingFactor method applied to a cooling coil?
output: If method FoulingFactor is used the air-side and water-side fouling are applied respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for adjusting UA_air using the FoulingFactor method for a cooling coil?
output: UA_air = [\\frac1UA_air + FaultFrac \\cdot \\fracr_airA_out]^-1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is \(A_out\)?
output: \(A_out\) is the Outside Coil Surface Area (in contact with the air) m\(^2\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is \(A_ratio\)?
output: \(A_ratio\) is the Inside to Outside Coil Surface Area Ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: Is the pressure drop associated with fouling considered in the current implementation?
output: The pressure drop associated with the fouling is ignored in the current implementation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What schedule is used to schedule the fault on or off?
output: An Availability schedule is used to schedule the fault on or off.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is a Severity Schedule used for?
output: A Severity Schedule is used to represent the severity of the fault or Fault Fraction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What does a schedule value of 1 mean?
output: Schedule value of 1 (default) means that the fault is applied as is.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Heating Coil -> text
input: What happens when a fault is applied to a Coil:Heating:Water?
output: When applied to a Coil:Heating:Water before the fault is applied the current non-fouled UA (WaterCoil(CoilNum).UACoilVariable) is first determined.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Heating Coil -> text
input: What does the method FouledUARated do?
output: If method FouledUARated is used we try to set the new \(UA\) to the \(UA_fouled\) entered in the Fouling Object adjusting for Fault Severity \(FaultFrac\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Heating Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation used for UA when the FouledUARated method is applied?
output: The equation is \(UA = \left[\fracFaultFracUA_fouled+\frac(1-FaultFrac)UA\right]^-1\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Heating Coil -> text
input: What does the method FoulingFactor do?
output: If method FoulingFactor is used the fouling factor is calculated based on the formula provided.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Heating Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(R_foul\) in the FoulingFactor method?
output: The equation is \(R_foul = FaultFrac \cdot \left[ \fracr_waterA_out \cdot A_ratio + \fracr_airA_out \right]\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Heating Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for UA when the FoulingFactor method is applied?
output: The equation is \(UA = \left[\frac1UA + R_foul\right]^-1\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Heating Coil -> text
input: What is the final result for UA in the FoulingFactor method?
output: The final result is \(UA = min(UA UA)\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> text
input: What happens when a fault is applied to a Coil:Cooling:Water?
output: When applied to a Coil:Cooling:Water before the fault is applied the current non-fouled \(UA_water\) and \(UA_air\) are first determined.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> text
input: How is the FoulingFactor method applied to a cooling coil?
output: If method FoulingFactor is used the air-side and water-side fouling are applied respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(UA_air\) in the FoulingFactor method?
output: The equation is \(UA_air = \left[\frac1UA_air + FaultFrac \cdot \fracr_airA_out\right]^-1\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(UA_water\) in the FoulingFactor method?
output: The equation is \(UA_water = \left[\frac1UA_water + FaultFrac \cdot \fracr_waterA_out \cdot A_ratio\right]^-1\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> text
input: What does the method FouledUARated do for cooling coils?
output: If method FouledUARated is used the total \(UA_fouled\) of the coil is specified but we still have to split the fouling between External (air) and Internal (water).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the current split ratio \(S_R\)?
output: The equation is \(S_R = \fracUA_waterUA_air\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(UA_water\) using the split ratio \(S_R\)?
output: The equation is \(UA_water = S_R \cdot UA_air\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(UA\) using the split ratio \(S_R\)?
output: The equation is \(UA = \left[\frac1UA_air + \frac1S_R \cdot UA_air\right]^-1\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(UA\) as a function of \(UA_air\) and \(S_R\)?
output: The equation is \(UA = \fracUA_air \cdot S_R1 + S_R\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(UA\) when adjusting for Fault Fraction using \(UA_fouled\)?
output: The equation is \(UA = \left[\fracFaultFracUA_fouled+\frac(1-FaultFrac)UA\right]^-1\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(UA\) involving \(UA_air\) \(S_R\) and FaultFrac?
output: The equation is \(\fracUA_air \cdot S_RS_R + 1 = \left[\fracFaultFracUA_fouled+\frac(1-FaultFrac)\fracUA_air \cdot S_RS_R + 1\right]^-1\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> equation
input: What are the equations for \(UA_air\) and \(UA_water\) in terms of \(S_R\) and FaultFrac?
output: The equations are \(UA_air = \left[\fracFaultFrac \cdot S_R(S_R+1) \cdot UA_fouled+\frac(1-FaultFrac)UA\right]^-1\) and \(UA_water = S_R \cdot UA_air\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Modeling Approach - Cooling Coil -> text
input: What is the final result for UA in either the FoulingFactor or FouledUARated methods?
output: The final result in either case is \(UA = min(UA UA)\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: What is the symptom of air filter fouling?
output: Increased air loop system resistance resulting in a different system curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: How does air filter fouling affect fans?
output: It directly affects the operation of corresponding fans leading to variations in fan pressure rise fan energy consumption and the enthalpy of the fan outlet air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: What other system components are affected by air filter fouling?
output: It may lead to a reduction in airflow rate and thus affects the performance of other system components such as the heat transfer performance of heating/cooling coils.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for the heat transfer resistance of water?
output: \\fracr_waterA_out*A_ratio]^-1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is the method used to specify the total fouled UA of the coil?
output: FouledUARated: If method FouledUARated is used the total UA_fouled of the coil is specified but we still have to split the fouling between External (air) and Internal (water).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is the initial step in calculating the new split ratio for fouling?
output: We start by calculating the current split ratio S_R between internal and external and will use it for the new split.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for the current split ratio S_R?
output: S_R = UA_water / UA_air

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What are the equations for UA_water and UA_air in terms of S_R?
output: \\beginarrayl UA_water = S_R \\cdot UA_air \\\\ UA _water = S_R \\cdot UA _air \\endarray

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for the overall heat transfer coefficient UA?
output: \\beginarrayl UA = [\\frac1UA_air + \\frac1UA_water]^-1 \\\\ UA = [\\frac1UA_air + \\frac1S_R \\cdot UA_air]^-1 \\\\ UA = \\fracUA_air \\cdot S_R1 + S_R \\endarray

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for UA considering the fault fraction?
output: UA = [\\fracFaultFracUA_fouled+\\frac(1-FaultFrac)UA]^-1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation that relates UA_air S_R and FaultFrac?
output: \\fracUA _air \\cdot S_RS_R + 1 = [\\fracFaultFracUA_fouled+\\frac(1-FaultFrac)\\fracUA_air \\cdot S_RS_R + 1]^-1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What are the equations for UA_air and UA_water considering FaultFrac and S_R?
output: \\beginarrayl UA _air = [\\fracFaultFrac \\cdot S_R(S_R+1) \\cdot UA_fouled+\\frac(1-FaultFrac)UA]^-1 \\\\ UA _water = S_R \\cdot UA _air \\endarray

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is the condition for the final result of UA in fouling calculations?
output: Note that we do not allow bettering the coil UA so the final result in either cases is UA = min(UA UA)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: What is a symptom of air filter fouling?
output: Increased air loop system resistance resulting in a different system curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: How does air filter fouling affect fan operation?
output: This directly affects the operation of corresponding fans. More specifically it may lead to variations of the fan pressure rise fan energy consumption as well as the enthalpy of the fan outlet air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: What is one effect of air filter fouling on system performance?
output: It may also lead to a reduction in the airflow rate and thus affects the performance of other system components (e.g. heat transfer performance of heating/cooling coils).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: How is the fouling air filter fault described in EnergyPlus?
output: The fouling air filter fault is described in the object FaultModel:Fouling:AirFilter which refers to the fan objects that describe the associated fan.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: What are the types of fan objects associated with the fouling air filter fault?
output: The fan object can be Fan:ConstantVolume Fan:OnOff or Fan:VariableVolume.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: How are design pressure rise variations described in faulty cases?
output: The design pressure rise variations of the associated fan in the faulty cases are described by the Pressure Fraction Schedule specified in FaultModel:Fouling:AirFilter object which is used as a multiplier to the fault-free fan design pressure rise specified in the fan object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: How can variations of the design air flow rate be calculated?
output: The variations of the design air flow rate of the fan can then be calculated with the Pressure Fraction Schedule and Fan Curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: What happens when EMS is used to overwrite the pressure/MassFlow?
output: When EMS is used to overwrite the pressure/MassFlow the EMS values are used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: What factors relate to the effect of the fouling air filter on fan performance?
output: The effect of the fouling air filter on the fan performance is related with a number of factors including the fan types fan curves and system design and operating conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: What are the three possible situations in modeling dirty air filters?
output: In general there are three possible situations to be addressed in modeling dirty air filters.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: What happens when the required airflow rate is maintained by a variable speed fan running at higher speed?
output: In this case the fan operation state changes from point A (intersection of the fan curve corresponding to a lower speed and the system curve with clean filters) to point B (intersection of the fan curve corresponding to a higher speed and the system curve with dirty filters) as shown in Figure~\\reffig:effect-of-dirty-air-filter-on-variable-speed. Point B corresponds to a higher fan pressure rise than Point A and the same air flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is depicted in the figure related to the effect of dirty air filters on fan operation?
output: The figure shows the effect of dirty air filter on variable speed fan operation – flow rate maintained.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Air Filter Fouling -> text
input: How is the required airflow rate maintained while the fan pressure rise is increased?
output: The required airflow rate m can be maintained while the fan pressure rise \\(\\Delta P\\) is increased to \\(\\Delta P_df\\). This leads to higher fan power \\(\\dot Q_totdf\\) and higher power entering the air \\(\\dot Q_toairdf\\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What fan objects are referenced by FaultModel:Fouling:AirFilter?
output: FaultModel:Fouling:AirFilter refers to the fan objects that describe the associated fan which can be Fan:ConstantVolume Fan:OnOff or Fan:VariableVolume.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How is the design pressure rise variation of the associated fan in faulty cases described?
output: The design pressure rise variations of the associated fan in the faulty cases are described by the Pressure Fraction Schedule specified in FaultModel:Fouling:AirFilter object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What is the Pressure Fraction Schedule used for?
output: The Pressure Fraction Schedule is used as a multiplier to the fault-free fan design pressure rise specified in the fan object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: How can the variations of the design air flow rate of the fan be calculated?
output: The variations of the design air flow rate of the fan can be calculated with the Pressure Fraction Schedule and Fan Curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What happens when EMS is used to overwrite the pressure/MassFlow?
output: When EMS is used to overwrite the pressure/MassFlow the EMS values are used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What factors are related to the effect of the fouling air filter on fan performance?
output: The effect of the fouling air filter on fan performance is related to factors including fan types fan curves and system design and operating conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What are the three possible situations to be addressed in modeling dirty air filters?
output: The three possible situations are: (a) The required airflow rate can be maintained by the variable speed fan running at higher speed (b) The variable speed fan cannot increase in speed sufficiently to maintain the required airflow rate and (c) The fan operation state changes due to system or equipment constraints.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure 345 illustrate?
output: Figure 345 illustrates the effect of a dirty air filter on variable speed fan operation where the flow rate is maintained.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What happens to the fan pressure rise and fan power when the required airflow rate is maintained?
output: The fan pressure rise is increased to \(\Delta P_df\) leading to higher fan power \(\dot Q_totdf\) and higher power entering the air \(\dot Q_toairdf\) changing the specific enthalpies of the fan outlet air stream (\(h_outdf\)).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the formula for the flow fraction or part-load ratio?
output: The formula for the flow fraction or part-load ratio is \(f_flowdf = m / m_designdf\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the formula for the part load factor?
output: The formula for the part load factor is \(f_pldf = c_1 + c_2*f_flowdf + c_3*f_flowdf^2 + c_4*f_flowdf^3 + c_5*f_flowdf^4\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: How is the total fan power calculated in the dirty filter case?
output: The total fan power is calculated as \(\dotQ_totdf = f_pldf \times m_designdf \times \Delta P_df / (e_tot \times \rho_air )\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the formula for the fan shaft power in the dirty filter case?
output: The formula for the fan shaft power is \(\dotQ_shaftdf = e_motor \times \dotQ_tot df\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What changes occur in the fan power and airflow when a constant speed fan cannot maintain the design airflow rate?
output: The airflow rate m is reduced to m_df while the fan pressure rise ΔP is increased to ΔP_df resulting in variations of the fan power (Q̇_tot) the power entering the air (Q̇_toair) and the specific enthalpies of the fan outlet air stream (h_out).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for Q̇_totdf in the case of a constant speed fan?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What happens when the fan operation state changes due to dirty filters?
output: The fan operation state changes from point A (intersection of the fan curve and the system curve with clean filters) to point B (intersection of the fan curve and the system curve with dirty filters) resulting in a higher fan pressure rise and a lower air flow rate than Point A.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure 347 depict?
output: Figure 347 depicts the effect of a dirty air filter on constant speed fan operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> text
input: What are the effects of reduced airflow rate and increased fan pressure rise on the fan power and air stream?
output: The airflow rate is reduced to \(m_df\) while the fan pressure rise is increased to \(\Delta P_df\) resulting in variations of the fan power (\(\dot Q_tot\)) the power entering the air (\(\dot Q_toair\)) and the specific enthalpies of the fan outlet air stream (\(h_out\)).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total fan power in the dirty filter case?
output: \(\dotQ_totdf = m_designdf \times \Delta P_df / (e_tot \times \rho_air )\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
input: What is the equation for the fan shaft power in the dirty filter case?
output: \(\dotQ_shaftdf = e_motor \times \dotQ_tot df\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Operational Faults -> Section: Introduction to HVAC Operational Faults Modeling -> equation
